newsitem.title: USA: US Southeast power rebounds ahead of cooler temps.
newsitem.headline: US Southeast power rebounds ahead of cooler temps.

text.p: Spot bulk electricity prices in the U.S. Southeast rebounded Friday, in response to cooler weather forecasts and slightly stronger natural gas prices, market sources said.
Temperatures in the Southeast are expected to remain about 10-20 degrees above-normal through Saturday and then return to more seasonable levels Monday and Tuesday.

Firm, peak power prices in the northern part of the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) territory for Monday were assessed sharply higher in the $18.00-19.00 per megawatt hour (MWh) range, as compared with Thursday's $9.50-10.50 trading range.
Firm, off-peak electricity in northern TVA for Monday was assessed at $13.00 per MWh.
For Saturday and Sunday delivery, peak, firm prices into TVA were talked in the $15.00-16.00 range.
At the Georgia/Florida border, prices for firm, peak electricity in 16 hour blocks for Monday delivery were talked about $3 higher in the $22.00-23.00 range.
Firm, off-peak power for Monday at the Ga./Fla. border was notionally around $16.00.

In Florida, where daytime temperatures are reaching highs of 70s and 80s and lows of 50s and 60s, firm, peak electricity prices on a 16-hour schedule for Monday were also higher around $25.00 per MWh.
Helping to lift electricity prices was the stronger natural gas market. Weekend prices along the Gulf Coast rose by about five cents to the $2.54-2.60 per million British thermal units range.
